Word problems in argument forms

E.g.
Show that the premises

$\neg p:$ "It is not sunny this afternoon"
and $q:$ "It is colder than yesterday"
and $r:$ "We will go swimming only if it is sunny"
and $s:$ "If we do not go swimming, then we will take a canoe trip"
and $t:$ "If we take a canoe trip then will be home by sunset"

imply the conclusion $t$ (for conditional statements, the variables given above are there results)

$\neg p \land q$
($\therefore \neg p$)
$r \implies p$
($\therefore \neg r$)
$\neg r \implies s$
($\therefore s$)
$s \implies t$
$\therefore t$

Is this a valid argument form? (Indications in parentheses are not from the original premises, but rather implied by them)

To justify an argument format, you number each step and give reasons for each.

(1) $\neg p \land q$        [premise]
(2) $\neg p$                [rule of inference]
(3) $r \implies p$          [premise]
(4) $\neg r$                [rule of inference, (2,3)]
(5) $\neg r \implies s$     [premise]
(6) $s$                     [rule of inference, (4,5)]
(7) $s \implies t$          [premise]
(8) $t$                     [rule of inference, (6,7)]
$\square$

Fallacies

Fallacy of affirming the conclusion: $(p \implies q) \land q \implies p$
Fallacy of denying the hypothesis: $(p \implies q) \land \neg p \implies \neg q$

For quantifiers

With $\forall x$ we should be able to give a value to $x$ and eliminate the quantifier (universal instantiation)
$(\forall x : P(x)) \implies P(c)$ for any $c \in D[x]$ (domain)
$(\exists x : P(c)) \implies P(c)$ for some $c \in D[x]$ (existential instantiation)

We also have their converses (universal and existential generalization)
